Content:
From recent reviews it seems that the AtomicDex is fantastic. really Great job!
I haven't tried it yet a but I also haven't seen a screenshot of AtomicDEX that contains 
an optional reporting service as in CEX's (deposit, transactions/trade history, withdrawals), I hope it has this option.

and need to prove the source of our funds to government, IRS and banks it's going to be a nightmare.

Author: bishop#9773
Content: In the US, you can claim capital losses on crypto. You're just limited to offsetting your capital gains or if you have done that/have no gains, then $3000 with a carry-forward into future tax years. It got real messy for filers when they booked profits in the December 2017 run up just to roll  back into btc or alts and then subsequently booked losses in 2018/2019.

Author: zatJUM#9924
Content:
I'm not a dev (so I can't find if there's relevant code for this).
I'm running komodod on a "ipv6 only" vps (just copied komodod there as github isn't reachable through ipv6).
For it to run, I had to modify in ~/.komodo/komodo.conf from `rpcbind=127.0.0.1` to `rpcbind=::1`.
Now it seems to sync (`du -hs ~/.komodo` is growing).
I can't check this with `komodo-cli`: ```komodo-cli getinfo
error: couldn't connect to server: unknown (code -1)
(make sure server is running and you are connecting to the correct RPC port)```
It seems `127.0.0.1` is hardcoded somewhere in komodo-cli.
Can you confirm?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: seems possible

Author: zatJUM#9924
Content: Well, it is. I've found a way to use anyway: `komodo-cli -rpcconnect=::1 getinfo`

Author: zatJUM#9924
Content: Thanks

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: @zatJUM 127.0.0.1 bind doesn't hardcoded (I wonder), I've binded to 0.0.0.0 lets say with needed IP allowed for remote RPC calls

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Used `rpcbind=0.0.0.0 + rpcallowip=rpcclientip` Not sure about ipv6

Author: Small Fish#5687
Content: @jl777c what is your take on quantum computers? Specially what kind of cryptography do you think can protect DLT from this threat?                    The day where true quantum computer are in the wild seem closer and closer.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dilithium is a QC resistant signature method and we already have an antara module for it

Content: so would world banks lol

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: I recommend you to read this article first, to understand what kind of threats QC could cause to Bitcoin <https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Quantum_computing_and_Bitcoin>

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: actually the notarization would be fine as its existence is its proof. granted the QC could be spending the fees, but likely they would go after much bigger addresses first

Content: Thank!

Content: by the time the big BTC addresses are being QC attacked, we need to be in the process of converting to dilithium or equivalent
